botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort, skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives in neutral to alkaline soils that are moist, fertile and humus-rich. Partial shade is ideal but can tolerate full sun. Provide shelter from strong, cold winds. Mulch annually in autumn. See hellebore cultivation for more details
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division of large clumps in early spring, watering well until they are established
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove old leaves to help prevent hellebore leaf spot, and deadhead to encourage more flowers
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to slugs, snails, hellebore aphid, hellebore leaf miner, chafer grubs, vine weevil and mice
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to hellebore black death, hellebore leaf spot, downy mildews, grey moulds (botrytis), smuts, and virus diseases
